question: Air bronchogram on chest Xray denotes -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i.e., Intrapulmonary lesionAir bronchogramo Normally, air in the bronchi through normal lung parenchyma is not visible as the wall of the bronchi are very thin and they are surrounded by air in the alveoli. Howerver, if the surrounding alevoli are opacified (e.g., in consolidation), air in bronchi become visible as linear branching structure. Because air in bronchi is visualized it is called air bronchogram. Air bronchogram indicates intrapulmonary pathology. It excludes any pleural or mediastinal pathology . Air bronchogram can be caused by : -Common causes : - Consolidation (m.c. cause), Pulmonary edema, Hyaline membrane disease.Less common causes : - Sarcoidosis, lymphoma, alveolar proteinosis, ARDS, Alveolar cell carcinoma. Normal person w ith phase of long exposure.

question: A young man with tuberculosis presents with massive recurrent hemoptysis. For angiographic treatment which vascular structure should be evaluated first
exp: Ans. is 'b' i.e., Bronchial artery Most common vessel responsible for the hemoptysis in TB (or even in Bronchitis, Bronchiectasis, or Bronchogenic carcinoma) are the bronchial arteriesSchwartz surgery writes - "As with lung abscess and bronchiectasis, the intense inflammatory process in the periphery of a tuberculous cavity tends to promote hypertrophy of bronchial arterial and pulmonary arterial branches. These may be eroded by the necrotizing processin the centre of the cavity to produce hemoptysis. The vessel responsible is most frequently a dilated bronchial arterial branch, referred to as a Rasmussen aneurysm"
